story.description: An older man, Andrew Marsh, is seen viewing a homemade pornographic tape. It is later revealed the man died from complications stemming from erotic asphyxiation. The main suspect is the woman having sex with Marsh in the film, Rebecca Carlson (Madonna), who after being charged with murder is represented by lawyer Frank Dulaney (Willem Dafoe).

story.description: The trial begins in Portland, Oregon and it isn't long before Rebecca and Frank enter a sadomasochistic sexual relationship behind the back of Dulaney's unsuspecting wife (Julianne Moore). Their rough sex goes so far that Rebecca drips hot candle wax onto Frank.

story.description: Rebecca proclaims her innocence to Frank in private as well as in court, but the prosecutor and district attorney Robert Garrett (Joe Mantegna) is out to prove that Rebecca Carlson deliberately killed Marsh in bed with sex to receive the $8 million he left her in his will.

Chinese peony roots.
What's it used for?
What's it used for?
- It's an aspirin substitute. - Tell him why.
She suffers from dysmenorrhea.
She suffers from dysmenorrhea.
Cramps.
Cramps.
Miss Carlson, I'm ready whenever you are.
Thank you.
You're supposed to be on my side, Frank.
Could've at least given me the benefit of the doubt.
Could've at least given me the benefit of the doubt.
You're right. I'm sorry.
You're right. I'm sorry.
Do you mind waiting 15 minutes?
Not at all.
Not at all.
Look around.
Just a little pain in the lumbar.
Here, pussy-puss.
Hello, kitty.
Such a beautiful kitty.
Is it still raining?
Is it still raining?
Can you drive me home?
Sure. I'll give you a ride home.
Sure. I'll give you a ride home.
I've never been in one of these.
Now's your chance.
Come in.
It's a bad idea.
Why?
Why?
I'm your lawyer. It doesn't look good.
I'm your lawyer. It doesn't look good.
Nobody's looking.
Nobody's looking.
Good night, Rebecca.
Are you scared?
Are you scared?
Not if you tell me I shouldn't be.
Not if you tell me I shouldn't be.
We're going to kick their ass.
We're going to kick their ass.
All rise.
All rise.
Superior Court for the county of Multnomah...
is now in session.
The Honorable Judge Mabel Burnham presiding.
The Honorable Judge Mabel Burnham presiding.
I can't change the titillating nature of this trial...
but if I had wanted to work in a circus...
I would've learned how to ride a trapeze...
I would've learned how to ride a trapeze...
so I will not put up with any performances...
by counsel or by the gallery.
by counsel or by the gallery.
Are the people ready to proceed, Mr. Garrett?
Are the people ready to proceed, Mr. Garrett?
Yes, Your Honor.
Andrew Marsh made what turned out to be...
a fatal mistake.
He fell in love.
He fell in love...
with a ruthless, calculating woman...
who went after an elderly man with a bad heart...
and a big bank account.
and a big bank account.
You all can see the defendant, Rebecca Carlson...
You all can see the defendant, Rebecca Carlson...
but as this trial proceeds...
you will see she's not only the defendant...
she is the murder weapon itself.
she is the murder weapon itself.
If I hit you...
If I hit you...
and you die...
I am the cause of your death...
but can I be called a weapon?
but can I be called a weapon?
The answer is yes...
and what a deadly weapon Rebecca Carlson made.
and what a deadly weapon Rebecca Carlson made.
The state will prove that she seduced Andrew Marsh...
and manipulated his affections...
until he rewrote his will, leaving her $8 million...
until he rewrote his will, leaving her $8 million...
that she insisted on increasingly strenuous sex...
knowing he had a severe heart condition...
knowing he had a severe heart condition...
and when that didn't work fast enough for her...
she secretly doped him with cocaine.
she secretly doped him with cocaine.
His heart couldn't take the combination...
His heart couldn't take the combination...
and she got what she wanted.
She is a beautiful woman...
but when this trial is over...
you will see her no differently than a gun or a knife...
you will see her no differently than a gun or a knife...
or any other instrument used as a weapon.
or any other instrument used as a weapon.
She's a killer...
and the worst kind-
and the worst kind-
a killer who disguised herself as a loving partner.

story.description: Frank can't resist Rebecca sexually but he doesn't trust her. His wife sees telltale marks on his flesh and realizes he's been having an affair. Rebecca is shown in court to have had previous sexual relationships with a number of older rich men, including Jeffery Roston (Frank Langella), in which her lovemaking was just as rough, indicating that what she did with Marsh was not unusual.

sentences: Yes, it would be nice.
Yes, it would be nice.
What would?
What would?
You and I making love.
You and I making love.
Is that what you think I was thinking?
Is that what you think I was thinking?
There's nothing wrong with admitting you want me.
There's nothing wrong with admitting you want me.
You take a lot for granted.
You take a lot for granted.
Frank... go home.
Thanks for dinner.
Good night.
My way.
Are you scared?
Are you scared?
No.
No.
Would you see if Michael's up yet?
The people would like to recall Dr. Alan Paley to the stand.
Dr. Paley, you're still under oath here.
Dr. Paley, you're still under oath here.
Take it seriously.
Do you know Rebecca Carlson?
Yes.
Did you, in fact, date Miss Carlson?
Did you, in fact, date Miss Carlson?
Yes, we dated.
Yes, we dated.
Keep your rude mouths shut or get out of my courtroom.
Keep your rude mouths shut or get out of my courtroom.
Keep your rude mouths shut or get out of my courtroom.
This is the only time I'll ask nicely.
This is the only time I'll ask nicely.
Proceed, Mr. Garrett.
Did you ever discuss...
Did you ever discuss...
anything about your patient, Mr. Marsh, with her?
anything about your patient, Mr. Marsh, with her?
His picture was on the social page...
and I mentioned that I'd treated him.
and I mentioned that I'd treated him.
What was her reaction?
What was her reaction?
She was fascinated.
She was fascinated.
Did she ask you anything in particular about him?
Did she ask you anything in particular about him?
She wanted to know...
whether cocaine would kill him if he tried it again.
whether cocaine would kill him if he tried it again.
And what did you say?
And what did you say?
I told her it would be a Russian roulette.
I told her it would be a Russian roulette.
Your witness.
Dr. Paley, why didn't you mention...
your relationship with Rebecca earlier?
your relationship with Rebecca earlier?
Nobody asked me.
Nobody asked me.
Did you have sexual relations with her?
Objection-irrelevant.
Your Honor, if you'll allow some latitude...
I can establish the relevance.
I can establish the relevance.
You'd better. Objection overruled.
The witness is directed to answer the question.
The witness is directed to answer the question.
No.
No.
No, you did not have sexual relations?
No, you did not have sexual relations?
No, we didn't.
No, we didn't.
Because she refused to have sex with you.
Objection-Your Honor...
the counsel is trying to manufacture-
the counsel is trying to manufacture-
Get up here, both of you!
Get up here, both of you!
Mr. Dulaney, if you're just bottom-feeding...
Mr. Dulaney, if you're just bottom-feeding...
you're going to choke on the mud.
you're going to choke on the mud.
I'm working toward a specific point, Your Honor.
I'm working toward a specific point, Your Honor.
Work fast.
I'm getting tired of seeing you this close to me.
Objection overruled.
Objection overruled.
Dr. Paley, do you remember your last date...
with Rebecca at the Cat and Fiddle restaurant?
with Rebecca at the Cat and Fiddle restaurant?
It wasn't that memorable.
Well, do you remember...
Well, do you remember...
trying to force yourself on her in the parking lot?
trying to force yourself on her in the parking lot?
Objection!
Objection!
I can bring in the parking attendant...
and two customers to refresh your memory if I have to.
and two customers to refresh your memory if I have to.
I didn't hear the reason for your objection, Mr. Garrett.
I didn't hear the reason for your objection, Mr. Garrett.
Wasn't that the last time you saw Rebecca...
until appearing in court, Dr. Paley?
until appearing in court, Dr. Paley?
I don't remember the last time I saw her.
In fact, didn't you attempt...
to blackmail her into seeing you again...
by threatening to falsely testify against her?
No. You're crazy.
No. You're crazy.
Your Honor, I have a tape...
from Rebecca's answering machine I'd like to play.
Objection-we don't know where this tape is from...
or who made it, or under what circumstance.
May I approach?
May I approach?
I have reports from two independent audio labs...
I have reports from two independent audio labs...
that Mr. Garrett himself has used to verify evidence...
that Mr. Garrett himself has used to verify evidence...
in other trials.
They both conclude that the voice on the tape...
was recorded over the phone, with no tampering.
was recorded over the phone, with no tampering.
I'll allow it.
I'll allow it.
I know you're there.
Pick up the phone, god damn it.
Pick up the phone, god damn it.
You think I won't do it?
I can put you away, Rebecca, for the rest of your life.
I can put you away, Rebecca, for the rest of your life.
You'd better call me...
or you're fucked one way or the other.
What did you mean, Dr. Paley?
What did you mean, Dr. Paley?
You never told her about Andrew Marsh, did you?
You never told her about Andrew Marsh, did you?
Yes, I did. She asked me, and I told her.
Yes, I did. She asked me, and I told her.
Perjury is a criminal charge, Doctor!
Perjury is a criminal charge, Doctor!
I am not lying.
I am not lying.
No further questions.
You were brilliant.
I didn't break him all the way.
You burned him down.
- Gabe, hit P3. - You got it.
- Gabe, hit P3. - You got it.
See you tomorrow.
See you tomorrow.
- OK. - Bye.
- OK. - Bye.
Could somebody hit P4, please?
Could somebody hit P4, please?
Thank you.
Let's go.
Somebody's going to see us.
Come on.
The people call Jeffrey Roston.
Do you know him?
Do you know him?
May I approach?
May I approach?
Your Honor, this witness has never been mentioned...
by the prosecution.
Our investigators didn't contact Mr. Roston...
until yesterday afternoon in New York.
What took so long?
He just came home from an extended vacation.
All right. I'm going to allow the testimony.
That's it, Counselor. Take a seat.
Mr. Roston, what was your relationship...
with Miss Carlson?
We were lovers.
How long were you together?
For about a year.
For about a year.
How would you describe your sex life with her?
How would you describe your sex life with her?
It was... very intense.
I know this is very personal...
I know this is very personal...
but I'm going to ask you to be more specific.
She was always trying...
to get me more and more worked up.
By what means?
I couldn't do everything she wanted in my condition.
What condition is that?
I had a bad heart.
What happened next?
What happened next?
I had bypass surgery.
How are you now?
I'm fine.
I'm fine.
My doctor says I can live to be a very old man.
How did your relationship with the defendant...
How did your relationship with the defendant...
progress after the surgery?
It just ground to a sudden halt. She left me.
Why did she say she was leaving?
She didn't. She just left.
Why do you think she left you?
Objection-question calls for a conclusion...
on the part of the witness.
Objection sustained.
When you say your sexual relations...
When you say your sexual relations...
with Miss Carlson were intense...
in what way?
It was as if she were trying to push me...
as far as she could.
Can you give the court an example?
Sex was a game to her.
She got off on the control.
She always used to tell me it had to be her way.
She always used to tell me it had to be her way.
A few nights before my bypass, I woke up...
and she'd tied me to the bed.
With handcuffs?
With handcuffs?
No...
with my own belt.
And what did she say?
Mr. Roston, I know this is difficult for you...
but it is important.
Please tell the court.
She said she was going to fuck me...
like I'd never been fucked before.
Bailiff, clear the courtroom.
Everyone except the reporters.
Everyone except the reporters.
After she tied you up, Mr. Roston...
what did she do next?
She started...
masturbating...
and telling me how much she wanted me inside her.
It drove me crazy.
Did your heart start to bother you?
Yeah.
We were making love...
and she was on top of me.
And every time I got close...
she'd stop.
And I couldn't take it.
I couldn't breathe.
I was suffocating.
I begged her.
I really thought that I was about to die.
I really thought that I was about to die.
Did you change your will...
while you were involved with Miss Carlson?
Yes.
And who was the primary beneficiary?
She was.
I was very much in love with her.
And I was a fool.
And I was a fool.
Thank you, Mr. Roston.
No further questions.
Counsel.
No questions.
I can explain everything.
I can explain everything.
You're a little late.
I needed to know before he testified!
Why the fuck didn't you warn me?
You need to hear about every man I ever had sex with?
Just the ones with bad hearts who put you in their wills!
You think I killed Andrew?
So does everyone in that courtroom!
You made me look like shit in there!
You are not on trial!
The hell I'm not!
The hell I'm not!
I must've been out of my mind to get involved with you.
To make love to me?
Yes.
But I'm not going to compound my mistakes.
You're my client. That's it.
I don't want anything to do with you beyond that.
Just like that?
Like I don't have any feelings?
Hey, I'm not your type.
I'm too young and healthy.
That's not fair, Frank.
No... but it's accurate.
Fuck you, too.
Hi.
Where's Michael?
I took him over to Kevin's to spend the night.
Why didn't you tell me? I could've stayed at the office.
I got a shitload of work.
You mean you could've screwed your client.
You mean you could've screwed your client.
You mean you could've screwed your client.
That's paranoid.
Oh, man.
Fine.
Go away!
Talk to me.
People see your car down by the river...
in front of her goddamn houseboat.
It gets back to me, Frank!
She's my client.
I'm allowed to have conferences with my client.
Why can't you have them in your office?
I can't believe you listen to this bullshit gossip.
I talked to her!
What?
She called here tonight looking for you.
What did she say?
She didn't have to say anything.
I could hear it in her voice.
In the way that she said your name.
You're making this up.
What did she do to you, Frank?
How did you get those marks on your chest?
What are they?
What are they, bites?
What happened to your back?
I thought we were happy.
I thought we were a family.
I trusted you.
It has nothing to do with you.
You son of a bitch.
How dare you stand there and say that to me?
I love you. You're my wife.
Go pack some things.
I don't want to see you when I get home.
Please, Sharon. I don't want to lose you.
Please, Sharon. I don't want to lose you.
Then you shouldn't have fucked her.

story.description: Taking the witness stand, Rebecca's emotional testimony that she did not mean to cause her older husband's death convinces the jury, which acquits her. Before leaving court, she mockingly thanks Frank for getting a guilty client off. Frank finally becomes fully aware that Rebecca indeed killed March delibrately with sex and worse still, he cannot repeat what she said because of the attorney-client privilage law. Frank also knows that Rebecca cannot be tried again because of the so-called "double jeopardy" law which states that no one can be tried twice for the same crime, even if the accused confesses or new evidence surfaces afterwords.

sentences: The defense calls Rebecca Carlson to the stand.
You swear to tell the truth, the whole truth...
and nothing but the truth, so help you God?
and nothing but the truth, so help you God?
I do.
I'd like you to recount, as you remember...
I'd like you to recount, as you remember...
the events on the night of April 8th.
We came home from dinner early.
And Andrew still had a cold...
so I thought I'd put him to bed and go home.
But you didn't go home, did you?
But you didn't go home, did you?
No. He wanted to make love.
No. He wanted to make love.
And that made me want to. He was a very physical man.
Would you say you loved him?
Would you say you loved him?
Very much.
Very much.
Why didn't you marry him?
Because his marriages never lasted.
I want it to last.
Rebecca, you heard the forensic testimony...
Rebecca, you heard the forensic testimony...
about the use of handcuffs.
What were they doing in the house?
Andrew bought them for Valentine's Day.
For you-
For you to use on him while you made love?
Yes. He liked that.
He was always in charge in his life and his work.
He was always in charge in his life and his work.
In bed, he liked to have somebody else in charge.
It was a game we played.
Watch yourselves, or I'll clear this courtroom again.
Rebecca, did Andrew indicate to you...
that he was having any problems at all...
like shortness of breath...
while you were making love that night?
No. He was fine.
And after you finished making love...
what did you do?
I kissed him good night, and I went home.
When did you find out he was dead?
Not until the next day.
And when did you find out...
And when did you find out...
you were a beneficiary of Andrew's will?
When you told me.
Your witness.
I'm less interested in your relationship...
with Andrew Marsh, the nature of which...
you've made abundantly clear...
than I am in your relationships...
with Jeffrey Roston and Dr. Alan Paley.
with Jeffrey Roston and Dr. Alan Paley.
How long after you stopped dating Dr. Paley...
did you start dating his patient Mr. Marsh?
It must have been about four months.
Four months in which you tried to meet your victim...
at galleries and museum openings?
Objection! Counsel's baiting the witness.
Not at all. I'm establishing premeditation.
By baiting the witness.
Overruled. Answer the question.
I never heard his name before I met him.
You never saw his picture in the paper?
I don't read the paper.
I don't read the paper.
Is it your sworn testimony, that by coincidence alone...
you happened to date both Andrew Marsh...
who died from a combination of sex and drugs...
and the doctor who treated him for drug poisoning?
Portland's a small city.
I even dated a man who dated a woman you dated.
Do you think you're capable...
of just answering the questions put to you?
I'm just trying to explain myself.
The night of Mr. Marsh's death...
were you watching a pornographic videotape...
you'd made of yourselves?
Objection as to the characterization!
Objection as to the characterization!
An explicit videotape?
Andrew used to say...
"Why watch strangers when you can watch friends?"
If you had finished having sex...
and Mr. Marsh was asleep as you stated...
why was the VCR still on when the police arrived?
Because I forgot to turn it off before I left.
Because Andrew Marsh was already dead...
and you were in a hurry to make your exit?
Objection! Argumentative isn't the word...
for counsel's approach to cross.
Sustained. Watch yourself, Mr. Garrett.
Miss Carlson...
Miss Carlson...
you stated that you handcuffed Andrew Marsh...
before having sex with him the night of his death.
before having sex with him the night of his death.
It wasn't before. It was during.
I stand corrected. Thank you.
I stand corrected. Thank you.
Did you engage in any other forms...
of dominance with the victim?
Did you, for example, beat him?
Objection!
Objection!
The specifics of the sexual relationship...
between the victim and the defendant...
have no bearing on the charges against her.
have no bearing on the charges against her.
The state has an obvious interest...
The state has an obvious interest...
in a pattern of abuse...
that ended with the death of the victim.
Answer the question, Miss Carlson.
Answer the question, Miss Carlson.
Succinctly, please.
I never hurt him.
Did you humiliate him?
I never humiliated him, either.
He picked the games.
You have a weakness...
for rich older men with bad hearts...
don't you, Miss Carlson?
I like confident men who aren't afraid to experiment.
They tend to be older.
And I own a gallery.
People I meet tend to have money.
I don't ask for profit-and-loss statements.
Are we supposed to believe...
Jeffrey Roston and Andrew Marsh are coincidences?
They had nothing to do with each other.
They both had bad hearts, didn't they?
And they both wrote you into their wills.
But I already testified...
But I already testified...
I didn't know anything about Andrew's heart.
But you knew about Roston's.
Yes.
And when you couldn't induce a heart attack...
before he had surgery to repair it...
you bailed out.
He wasn't any good to you. Isn't that right?
I left him when I found him in bed with someone else.
That was grounds for leaving...
as sexually liberated as you are?
I couldn't compete.
You couldn't compete! What was she possibly doing?
Using a razor blade?
Using a razor blade?
He was in bed with another man.
I never knew that about him.
I felt betrayed.
I couldn't handle it, so I left.
It was easier for him to think I left because of the money...
but I left because I couldn't stay.
but I left because I couldn't stay.
Mr. Roston isn't here to defend himself.
You can say anything you want.
You can say anything you want.
Yes, he is.
Yes, he is.
Ask him yourself.
No further questions.
Redirect, Mr. Dulaney?
Your Honor, the defense rests.
Ladies and gentlemen of the jury...
in the case of the People vs. Rebecca Carlson...
have you reached a verdict?
We have, Your Honor.
How do you find?
The jury finds the defendant...
not guilty.
not guilty.
The defendant is released.
This court is adjourned.
This court is adjourned.
- Thanks, Gabe. - Nice going.
Thanks.
You almost convinced me.
Trial's over, Frank.
Walk away.
Stop whining.
You knew you were going to blow your career.
You knew you were going to blow your career.
I'm doing you a favor.
I'm doing you a favor.
We will live happily ever after, but not together.
If you stick around me...
you'll get indicted for perjury and murder.
I'm home free. They can't try me twice...
but you are a different story.
Shit!
He heard us.
He's my lawyer. It's privileged.
I'd have given you the same goddamn defense.
I'd have given you the same goddamn defense.
But you wouldn't have been as believable.

story.description: Frank goes that night to Carlson's home, where he finds her with Marsh's doctor, Alan Payley (Jürgen Prochnow), freely discussing the way they both conspired to kill Marsh for his money. She's free and clear, but taunts Payley by telling him to lie low (as he could be convicted of perjury) and to leave because "I've already forgotten you."

sentences: Stop whining.
You knew you were going to blow your career.
You knew you were going to blow your career.
I'm doing you a favor.
I'm doing you a favor.
We will live happily ever after, but not together.

you'll get indicted for perjury and murder.

but you are a different story.
Shit!

But you wouldn't have been as believable.

I don't think we ever slept, did we, Frank?
I don't think we ever slept, did we, Frank?

Don't look so hurt, Alan.
I fucked you. I fucked Andrew. I fucked Frank.

That's what I do. I fuck.

So you're fucking Dr. Paley here...
and he mentions a rich patient-
a rich, delicate patient-
and you figure you can fuck yourself into the will.
You know how to do that.
I'm hard to resist.
I'm hard to resist.
The coke came from Dr. Paley, didn't it?
The coke came from Dr. Paley, didn't it?
Made it untraceable.
Why are you telling him?
He's telling us.
Fuck if you didn't play me perfectly.
Paley goes on the stand, makes you look guilty as hell.
Paley goes on the stand, makes you look guilty as hell.
Then you set me up to destroy him...
so I can make you look innocent.
Sort of a reverse character witness.
You're a real genius.
Sorry I can't say the same thing about you.
Sorry I can't say the same thing about you.
I always thought the message on the answering machine...
I always thought the message on the answering machine...
was a little over the top, but you even bought that.
was a little over the top, but you even bought that.
What are you doing here anyway...
What are you doing here anyway...
ambulance chasing?
Looking for a new client?
Looking for a new client?
Talk to Alan here. He thinks he's in trouble.
You don't give a shit about me.
You're right.
You're right.
I've forgotten you already.
I've forgotten you already.

story.description: Rebecca bluntly tells Frank that her sexual prowess is how she is able to make men do anything... including him. An enraged Payley lashes out at Rebecca physically and, after Dulaney pulls him off, Payley shoots her twice. She plunges from a window to her death in the water below.

and he mentions a rich patient-

story.description: In the final scene, as the police take Payley away, Frank turns to Garrett as the dead Rebecca is taken away and says, "You should have won the case Rob." Garrett coldly replies, "I did."

sentences: Do you believe in karma, Frank?
No.
Whatever you call it...
people usually get what they deserve...
except for lawyers.
You should have won the case.
I did.
